h3. Problem Definition

In Bitbucket Datacenter installation if BITBUCKET_SHARED_HOME is mounted with NFS  Version 4, there could be performance impacts. This need to be added as a suggestion in our [Install Bitbucket Data Center - Atlassian Documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/install-bitbucket-data-center-872139817.html]
h3. Suggested Solution

Add a suggestion to use NFS version 3 mount. Specify "nfs noatime,nfsvers=3" in the mount option
 E.g.
{code:java}
<server:/export> </mount-point> nfs noatime,nfsvers=3,lookupcache=pos,proto=tcp,rsize=65536,wsize=65536,hard,addr=<host> 0 0  
{code}
h3. Workaround

Use this ticket a reference until the documentation is updated.

*Background*:

My organization currently uses groups, which map to development teams, to control read/write access to our Bitbucket repositories. Depending on priorities and resource allocation, developers from other teams may be temporarily reallocated. In this case, we temporarily assign permissions to the individual user, which are then manually removed at a later date. Depending on timing, this can result in a developer having elevated permissions for longer than necessary.

*Request:*

When creating permissions, we would like to be able to specify one of the following:
 * The permission is ongoing
 * The date the permission expires
 * How many days the permission is valid for

For all permissions that are not ongoing, we would like Bitbucket to automatically remove the permission once it is no longer valid. The automated removal should be recorded in the audit log for tracking purposes. Viewing permissions through the admin UI should clearly indicate when/if the active permissions expire.

fields.description:
As a developer, I don't want to see a diff for a new file when the copyright header takes the similarity of files over the configured percentage.

 

Currently the copied/moved status is selected by the amount of the file that is common between files. That percentage has to be configured to be relatively low in order for refactoring to be marked correctly, however with small files it frequently means that only the copyright header is the common part. In order to resolve this problem, copyright headers should be ignored when calculating the percentage of commonality.

Copyright headers are relatively easy to recognise - they are generally before the first non-comment line of a file and include one of "copyright", "(c)", "©" or "license". Clearly a "comment" means different things to different languages and so the language might need to be detected, possibly based on the extension - or perhaps there would be few enough false positives that several styles of comment could be recognised.

Some pull requests can have a ton of comment threads on them.  Often, a user wants to be able to easily see any new replies to these comment threads.

Three ways of going about that are:
 # Getting notified about the replies through email.  Not ideal because:
 ## Users often batch emails to avoid getting too many from Bitbucket, but they still want to be able to quickly see new comment thread replies when they are actively reviewing a pull request.
 # Looking at the diff for the file that holds the comment thread.  Not ideal because:
 ## Further commits may have hidden the comment thread, even though the comments may not have been fully addressed.
 ## You have to remember the files with comment threads you want to check up on, as well as the location of the comment threads on those files.
 # Scroll through your entire Activity and look for new replies that you haven't seen before.

The third option can be unmanageable on pull requests with many comment threads, as you may have to scroll for an unreasonably long time to make it through the entire Activity (and the page loads up more Activity as you scroll, which also takes time).  

However, a simple improvement would be to reorder the Activity as new replies are posted on comment threads.  This would mean that if you have a comment thread that was buried at the very beginning of the Activity, if someone added a new reply to it, it would jump to the top of the Activity.

With such changes in place, you could scroll through your Activity until you get to a comment that has no new replies.  Everything above that comment has new replies.

At this point, I have to look at the “Recently closed” section of <https://example.com/dashboard>, but not only do those age out, if I’ve been actively reviewing patches that list will be really long. I don’t care about the patches that don’t have any additional comments since I (or another reviewer) approved the pull request, but there’s no way to filter those out.

Another use case:

1) I author a pull request, which is approved by reviewer A, and I land it.
2) Later, another reviewer makes a comment on the pull request.

Again, unless I wade through the “Recently closed” section on the dashboard, I might miss the additional feedback.

Ideally, I’d like a way to flag a pull request so it would always show up in a section on the dashboard until I unflag it.

We could take more advantage of Bitbucket's hard work to make Diff views if I could select two commits to compare in the Network view.  This would allow comparisons both outside of and during a Pull Request.  I often wonder "what was the change since that version?".  

*Insufficient alternatives:* The new feature "Diff of: changes since last reviewed" is sometimes helpful, but sometimes a person adds multiple commits, which makes each iterative change harder to follow.  With selectable diffs in Bitbucket, I could look at changes in a smaller scope.

I can currently click on a commit and get the diff since the previous commit, but some people make a lot of commits that should have been squashed (but weren't).  

*Example:* The PR I am reviewing now has a small but important architecture change we requested – on top of a lot of other changes, so it is unclear which part relates to the arch. change.  To see more clearly, I looked in the Network view, but I see there that I have to review each of six final commits to get his change, plus bugfix1, bugfix2, etc. for six commits.  I would rather just see a his final vs. six commits back.  I can probably figure out how to do this in Git manually, but Bitbucket has all the infrastructure to do it faster....

*Methods:* One way to implement it would be to have a button on the Network View page called "Compare Commits".  After selected, the screen could indicate that the next two nodes clicked will be compared.  Another way would be to put a checkmark/highlight by a node when it is clicked, and give a message "Select a second node to perform a comparison."  That could overwrite the current behavior of comparing the current commit with previous, because one can select the previous as their second choice.

 

This relates to BSERV-7223.  Sorry I can't make that reference in the normal way while in Create Issue.

When a pull request is merged, regardless of strategy, {{\-\-log}}-style semantics are used and information about the commits being merged is included in the message for the new commit. When the strategy creates a merge commit, {{\-\-log=20}} is used to ensure the resulting message is not oversized when a pull request merges a large number of commits.

Such a limitation is not applied to squash "merge" strategies, however, which can result in excessively large messages when a large number of commits are squashed. For example, a squash merge including 12,000+ commits can result in a commit message that is hundreds of megabytes in size. In addition to impacts on Bitbucket Server (see BSERV-10767), such messages can also cause downstream pain (for example, in build systems that use JGit to display commit details).

Similar limiting should be applied to squash "merge" messages as what is applied for other strategies that create merge commits.

We organize our code around technologies/tools/products, not around teams. Teams change more often than underlying technology. So, several teams may have repositories in a single project. If a team wants to make one of their repositories private, we can no longer use project-level permissions because there's now way to "turn off" a permission granted at the project level.

For example, we have a "SQL Server" project, for code relating to SQL Server. At the project level, we grant all users write access.

Someone has requested a "DBA" repository where our DBAs can commit SQL Server administration scripts. They don't want anyone to be able to read from this repository.

Now, we have to change the default access to all repositories in this project to "No Access", remove the all users "write" access, and update the permissions for each repository in the project to grant all users "write" access except the new DBA repository. In the future, we have to remember to apply these permissions on each new repository in the SQL Server project.

Ugh. What I want to be able to do is instead, go into the DBA repository permissions and change the permissions that all users have to be "None".

"My understanding from the online KB is that a mirror will occasionally "phone home" to see if it needs to fetch, in the event the triggers were missed or couldn't be acted on. That appears to happen, but has some form of "stop trying" logic built in.

Due to our own issues, the mirror was out of sync, and had failed to correct enough times that numerous repos were in a "stop trying" state, with no obvious way to get them out of it.

Because we didn't get a reply, we eventually discovered that if a remote user just did a push to the primary, that caused the expected trigger, and subsequent pull, and the repos self-repaired.

None of that was obvious anywhere. Remote users weren't pushing, and their pulls were out of date. So it was in limbo until we did a bunch of pushes to kick things.

It's worth mentioning that NONE of this had anything to do with networking. The IT person who built the mirror provisioned the disk incorrectly, and we ran out of space on the mirror, preventing the pulls, and putting the repos into the stop trying state.


The primary should support a sync status for each repo and offer a "trigger a sync" option in the event things get stuck like mine did."
